abstract.t: In Situ Operations, Administration and Maintenance (IOAM) is used for monitoring network performance and for detecting traffic bottlenecks and anomalies. This is achieved by incorporating IOAM information into in-flight data packets. This document introduces the concept of use case-driven IOAM profiles. An IOAM profile defines a use case or a set of use cases for IOAM, and an associated set of rules that restrict the scope and features of the IOAM specification, thereby limiting it to a subset of the full functionality.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: IOAM is used for monitoring traffic in the network by incorporating IOAM information into in-flight data packets.

This document introduces the concept of use case driven IOAM profiles. An IOAM profile defines a use case or a set of use cases for IOAM, and an associated set of rules that restrict the scope and features of the IOAM specification, thereby limiting it to a subset of the full functionality. Based on the guidelines in this document, it is expected that future documents may define one or more IOAM profiles. The current document does not specify any IOAM profiles.

The motivation for defining profiles is to limit the scope of IOAM features, allowing simpler implementation, verification, and interoperability testing in the context of specific use cases that do not require the full functionality of IOAM.

This document does not require any changes to the Data Fields for In-situ OAM . Furthermore, it is expected that future IOAM profile specifications will not require changes to IOAM, since a profile, by definition, derives a subset of the existing functionality.

section.title: Overview
section.t: A profile defines a set of rules that limit the scope or functionality of IOAM. By default, any detail in IOAM that is not specifically addressed or limited by the profile is as defined in IOAM . The rest of this section presents a set of topics that may be addressed in a profile specification. A profile may include some or all of these topics, and optionally other topics.

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: An IOAM profile should define the use case(s) for using the profile. The use case may describe deployment scenarios or specific applications that make use of IOAM data. The use case should typically define the required functionality from IOAM. For example, an IOAM profile may be defined such that it requires transit delay monitoring, but does not require path tracing. These requirements then affect which IOAM data fields are used in the profile.

section.title: Namespace-ID
section.t: IOAM namespaces are defined in Section 4.1 of . An IOAM profile can be bound to a specific Namespace-ID value or to a set of Namespace-ID values. Thus, a profile specification may request IANA to allocate one or more Namespace-ID values.

It should be noted that the Namespace-ID is typically used for other purposes, as specified in , and thus the scope of a Namespace and the scope of an IOAM profile are generally independent. However, some profiles may be defined in a way that binds the profile to a specific Namespace-ID value or to a specific Namespace-ID range. Conversely, a profile may also be defined without being bound to a specific Namesampe-ID, in which case the profile specification may not include the current section.

section.title: IOAM Options
section.t: IOAM information may be represented in one of four possible IOAM options: Pre-allocated Trace Option, Incremental Trace Option, Proof Of Transit (POT) Option, and Edge-to-Edge Option. An IOAM profile may specify a subset of allowed options. A profile may define some options as mandatory in the current profile, or some options as forbidden in the current profile.

For each IOAM option, a profile specification may limit the scope of the profile to certain features. For example, a profile may be defined to use the Incremental Trace Option such that only specific data types are used in the profile, while others are not.

section.title: IOAM Option Header Field Values
section.t: An IOAM profile may define specific values or specific value range for some of the fields in the IOAM option headers. For example, a profile may define a specific value that is allowed to be used in the Flags field of the trace option header.

section.title: Opaque State Snapshot
section.t: The Opaque State Snapshot, as defined in , is a variable length field that may be used in IOAM trace options. The Opaque State Snapshot is defined in a flexible Type/Length/Value manner. An IOAM profile may define a specific format for the Opaque State Snapshot including for example a specific length and a specific interpretation of the opaque data. In that case, the IOAM profile ought to also specify a Schema ID value.

section.title: Timestamp Format
section.t: A profile may specify a specific timestamp format to be used in IOAM data fields.

section.title: Profile Coexistence
section.t: An IOAM node may be configured to operate in one or more IOAM profiles. If more than one profile is enabled, there should be a way for IOAM nodes to distinguish between packets that use different IOAM profiles, e.g., using the Namespace-ID. Therefore, it is recommended that a profile specification includes a definition of how to distinguish between packets from different profiles.

section.title: Validity
section.t: When an IOAM transit node or an IOAM decapsulating node receives a packet with one or more IOAM options, it needs to detect which profile the packet is bound to. The node then needs to perform validity checks including verifying that the packet belongs to one of the profiles that is supported and enabled in the current node, and that all the IOAM options in the current packet conform to the profile specification.

An IOAM transit/decapsulating node that receives a packet with IOAM options that do not pass the validity check can either forward/decapsulate the packet without IOAM processing, or it can process the packet as a conventional IOAM-enabled packet, if it is able to do so and if the network policy allows this behavior.

section.t: This document does not include any requests from IANA.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security considerations of IOAM in general are discussed in . This document presents the concept of IOAM profiles; since an IOAM profile is a specific use case of IOAM, any security threat that is relevant to the profile is also relevant to the full-blown IOAM. Therefore, the current document does not present any new security considerations beyond .

Moreover, in some cases a profile may limit the set of features of IOAM in a way that reduces the set of potential threats compared a full implementation of IOAM. In fact, a particular IOAM profile can optimize a particular security posture or requirement.

section.title: Overview
section.t: This section presents an example of an IOAM profile specification. The profile makes use of the Hop limit, Node ID and Transit delay data fields, and is thus called the HNT profile for short.

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: This profile is intended for path tracing and transit delay monitoring, while using compact data with just two data fields per packet. The profile can be useful in networks with a large number of hops.

section.title: IOAM Options
section.t: The HNT profile makes use of the Incremental Trace Option. A packet that includes IOAM data according to the current profile includes a single IOAM option - the Incremental Trace Option. Specifically, two data fields are used in this profile: the Hop_Lim and node_id field, and the transit delay field.

section.title: IOAM Option Header Field Values
section.t: The IOAM-Trace-Type field in the header of the Incremental Trace Option in current profile has a fixed value; Bit 0 (the most significant bit) and Bit 4 are set, while the rest of the bits are zero, indicating the two data fields that are used in the option.

section.title: Opaque State Snapshot
section.t: The opaque state snapshot is never used in this profile. Note that the NodeLen field, as defined in , represents the length of the data excluding the opaque state snapshot. Since this field is not used in the current profile, the NodeLen represents the actual length of the data.

section.title: Profile Coexistence
section.t: It is assumed that the current profile is used in a confined administrative domain in which no other IOAM profiles are used. Therefore, it is assumed that the current profile does not coexist with other profiles.

section.title: Validity
section.t: An IOAM transit/decapsulating node that receives a packet with IOAM options that do not comply to the current profile should forward/decapsulate the packet without IOAM processing, if it is able to do so. If a decapsulating node is not able to decapsulate an IOAM option that is not compliant to the current profile, the packet is discarded.
